thread.title: Two Newport Aquarium shark rays are pregnant
thread.title_full: Two Newport Aquarium shark rays are pregnant

author: courier-journal.com
title: Two Newport Aquarium shark rays are pregnant
text:
The Newport Aquarium's two female shark rays, Sweet Pea and Sunshine, are both pregnant – the second and third documented cases of shark ray breeding under professional animal care.
Newport Aquarium announced the pregnancies on Wednesday after animal husbandry staff confirmed the the shark rays were pregnant using ultrasounds for Sweet Pea on Oct. 1 and for Sunshine on Oct. 8.
Newport Aquarium veterinarian Dr. Peter Hill, who conducted the ultrasounds, estimates Sweet Pea and Sunshine’s due dates are within two to three months. Sweet Pea is expected to deliver first.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Shark bridge opens at Newport Aquarium
“This is an exciting next step in realizing the goals of our shark ray breeding program,” said Eric Rose, executive director at Newport Aquarium. “Still, pregnancy is not without risk, so we are cautiously optimistic that both Sweet Pea and Sunshine will give birth to healthy shark ray pups."
Shark rays, a vulnerable species, are one level from endangered. Threats to shark rays include habitat destruction, pollution, overfishing and the use of their fins for products, including shark fin soup.
The public can still see Sweet Pea and Sunshine in the shark exhibit, but they may be taken off exhibit closer to their due dates. They will be moved to Newport Aquarium’s offsite animal health facility in Northern Kentucky.
Newport Aquarium established the world’s first shark ray breeding program in 2007, when a male shark ray named Scooter was introduced to the 385,000-gallon shark exhibit. In 2013, a second male shark ray named Spike was introduced to the aquarium’s signature exhibit.
Sweet Pea became the first shark ray to give birth while under professional animal care on Jan. 24, 2014.
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Rare shark ray at Newport Aquarium is reportedly pregnant
Newport Aquarium is open to the public 365 days a year and located across the Ohio River from downtown Cincinnati.
For information, visit www.newportaquarium.com
